item.title: w
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Because of the way networking works, packets - groups of data with headers as to what exactly the groups of data contain - consist of bytes. When you click an item in the client, it creates a packet with the bytes containing the values to make up an integer (4 bytes combined). However, to make packet ‘sniffing’ and cheating harder, the client adds a value like 128 to the item ID and when the server reads it, it simply subtracts the 128, which creates the original un-touched item ID. Also, your “readSignedWordA” would work just fine as “readUnsignedWordA”.

Read full topic

item.title: w
item.dc:creator: @Yesteryear Yesteryear
item.description:
@Yesteryear wrote:

[quote=“Sup22211, post:7, topic:515759”]I just want to understand why in client.java i see this
int item2ID3 = inStream.readSignedWordA();
And what this readSingedWordA will do i want to understand what i code
buffer[currentOffset++] = (byte)(i + 128);
buffer[currentOffset++] = (byte)(i >> 8);
What this willl do?
(if you need the readSignedWordA its here

	public int readSignedWordA() {
		currentOffset += 2;
		int i = ((buffer[currentOffset - 2] & 0xff) << 8) + (buffer[currentOffset - 1] - 128 & 0xff);
		if(i > 32767) {
			i -= 0x10000;
		}
		return i;
	}

I just want to understand why when i am making an int (like this) int item2ID3 = inStream.readSignedWordA();
this will represent my first item click?[/quote]
It reads a big-endian signed short special A from the buffer.
What do you mean by “making an int”

Read full topic

item.title: w
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

To quote your other thread:

[quote=“Yesteryear, post:4, topic:514913”]To explain endianness, please read this.

The A in writeBigEndianA is a special data type in the Runescape client.[/quote]
and

I/o?

The methods you posted are methods that write to a buffer in the same way OutputStreams writes to a stream. After you completed the data packet (a message over network) you write the buffer using the flush() method. (note that these methods are from the RSPS, and not from the Java api)

A buffer is just a container to hold data. In this case, a bunch of bytes. A stream is used to write to the underlying buffer.

Read full topic

item.title: w

item.description:

1.
public byte buffer[] = null;
public int currentOffset = 0;
public stream(byte abyte0[]) {
buffer = abyte0;
currentOffset = 0;
}
i have no idea what that would do. also what can i use this “byte[]” for? is the code above called I/O?
And this what this ?
2.
public void writeWordBigEndianA(int i) {
buffer[currentOffset++] = (byte)(i + 128);
buffer[currentOffset++] = (byte)(i >> 8);
}
